document.title: College Board AP Psycology Course Guide

ABBB872BACED441E834CE65C2E4B319D.description: Identify important  gures in social psychology (e g , Solomon Asch, Leon Festinger, Stanley Milgram, Philip Zimbardo)

DC4428B40AC949B88E9223F3F6532974.description: Discuss attitude formation and change, including persuasion strategies and cognitive dissonance

636DE497EA144DFBB346DD9CDC870A62.description: Describe the variables that contribute to altruism, aggression, and attraction

49A4F357E6B94ED2AEF37A3D3B953E52.description: Anticipate the impact of behavior on a self-ful lling prophecy

6681CBFDD8554E749F2E0BAE6345E491.description: Articulate the impact of social and cultural categories (e g , gender, race, ethnicity) on self-concept and relations with others

767A527231C24E639C9BF4D9671B9784.description: Describe processes that contribute to differential treatment of group members (e g , in-group/out-group dynamics, ethnocentrism, prejudice)

12A79AA23B924989A54F36A962B22B00.description: Predict the impact of the presence of others on individual behavior (e g , bystander effect, social facilitation)

B448FC0177084F2BB4D5AF87A7B648A9.description: Discuss attitudes and how they change (e g , central route to persuasion)

15CA28B156C547BDBD8A2596F5E4A90B.description: Explain how individuals respond to expectations of others, including groupthink, conformity, and obedience to authority

86209A0D022A4E4E844403109D926E58.description: Describe the structure and function of different kinds of group behavior (e g , deindividuation, group polarization)

9CDD906F62344B7286EC7C6C5622C939.description: Apply attribution theory to explain motives (e g , fundamental attribution error, self-serving bias)

9A18BBA4FEA84DA3A4F1763550A6B7A2.description: Identify major  gures in psychological treatment (e g , Aaron Beck, Albert Ellis, Sigmund Freud, Mary Cover Jones, Carl Rogers, B  F  Skinner, Joseph Wolpe)

1A72B8375BBC454BA0927CA889C7790C.description: Describe prevention strategies that build resilience and promote competence

4E70240032B44C39A2EC5223317C5769.description: Discuss how cultural and ethnic context in uence choice and success of treatment (e g , factors that lead to premature termination of treatment)

6BBBF56A7C1A49A581248313F20C4539.description: Summarize effectiveness of speci c treatments used to address speci c problems

1460CD0F63514902A455BB1C2D91DF5C.description: Compare and contrast different treatment formats (e g , individual, group)

F2A1819708E74138971221E926C8E505.description: Describe major treatment orientations used in therapy (e g , behavioral, cognitive, humanistic) and how those orientations in uence therapeutic planning

34A7C2E4AB594108B9CEE31400FBF3B5.description: Describe the central characteristics of psychotherapeutic intervention

0AD0CC5D907748009C9D873029924202.description: Discuss the intersection between psychology and the legal system (e g , con dentiality, insanity defense)

8E006496896643B9AEC50927CA5BE164.description: Identify the positive and negative consequences of diagnostic labels (e g , the Rosenhan study)

C243255B118347AEA79C35E7F4877FC9.description: Evaluate the strengths and limitations of various approaches to explaining psychological disorders: medical model, psychoanalytic, humanistic, cognitive, biological, and sociocultural

26889371534F4119AC06F2D04C046A9D.description: Discuss the major diagnostic categories, including anxiety disorders, bipolar and related disorders, depressive disorders, dissociative disorders, feeding and eating disorders, neurodevelopmental disorders, neurocognitive disorders, obsessive-compulsive and related disorders, personality disorders, schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders, somatic symptom and related disorders, and trauma- and stressor-related disorders and their corresponding symptoms

44FBC2B3328F463E9CA5BE1D559C9E60.description: Recognize the use of the most recent version of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) published by the American Psychiatric Association as the primary reference for making diagnostic judgments

6BC48DF17B244623AF6A3163E1005824.description: Describe contemporary and historical conceptions of what constitutes psychological disorders

48DB1B4A018544F19D07BF6C4E8AF2AE.description: Identify key contributors in intelligence research and testing (e g , Alfred Binet, Francis Galton, Howard Gardner, Charles Spearman, Robert Sternberg, Louis Terman, David Wechsler)

A02BDB81AC484A4EA2D6ED9E698B087A.description: Debate the appropriate testing practices, particularly in relation to culture-fair test uses

C8F4779CDF874E07A62BCFF634C3BD93.description: Describe relevant labels related to intelligence testing (e g , gifted, cognitively disabled)

65C6D587263E47EAAD466CED4AACDA7A.description: Interpret the meaning of scores in terms of the normal curve

AF3BB3BB2C9645338DEF50C1676031E5.description: Explain how psychologists design tests, including standardization strategies and other techniques to establish reliability and validity

EA55ACFC424F44BCB718AB0F6DB9888A.description: Compare and contrast historic and contemporary theories of intelligence (e g , Charles Spearman, Howard Gardner, Robert Sternberg)

112DEA35CD174C87A50D30091AC6EBCD.description: Discuss how culture in uences the de nition of intelligence

F7A6215EABFB4C279F13AEBA617C616D.description: Identify key contributors to personality theory (e g , Alfred Adler, Albert Bandura, Paul Costa and Robert McCrae, Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, Abraham Maslow, Carl Rogers)

F2C146111A644D02A992CE55984E9150.description: Speculate how cultural context can facilitate or constrain personality development, especially as it relates to self-concept (e g , collectivistic versus individualistic cultures)

50B03787B0E749F19C509517654EFDBF.description: Identify frequently used assessment strategies (e g , the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory [MMPI], the Thematic Apperception Test [TAT]), and evaluate relative test quality based on reliability and validity of the instruments

E1E010588BC449C8A8B59F88F7D9AA4E.description: Describe and compare research methods (e g , case studies and surveys) that psychologists use to investigate personality

CE48BD1140D34680A775FD77545953F3.description: Compare and contrast the major theories and approaches to explaining personality (e g , psychoanalytic, humanist, cognitive, trait, social cognition, behavioral)

5F405A313EDB43428057507472BB55D7.description: Identify key contributors in developmental psychology (e g , Mary Ainsworth, Albert Bandura, Diana Baumrind, Erik Erikson, Sigmund Freud, Carol Gilligan, Harry Harlow, Lawrence Kohlberg, Konrad Lorenz, Jean Piaget, Lev Vygotsky)

D50C4904DFC94515B0BEB1B2CB31EB25.description: Describe how sex and gender in uence socialization and other aspects of development

9CB70861357A4FC898D88D7D519E674F.description: Predict the physical and cognitive changes that emerge as people age, including steps that can be taken to maximize function

9DFC693C7AC4415FAD675DA6808B39CD.description: Characterize the development of decisions related to intimacy as people mature

5AA2867BF7A549EB91A055FB738ED42A.description: Explain how parenting styles in uence development

5894ED277EE747E3A227A87F45482A07.description: Discuss maturational challenges in adolescence, including related family con icts

3AD06E0293D448DAB9FFC96451DF0F61.description: Compare and contrast models of moral development (e g , Kohlberg, Gilligan)

EE912F4039324C0B8F102BBC73CAAE48.description: Explain the maturation of cognitive abilities (e g , Piaget’s stages, information processing)

BBC06F3C2DF34E61B653007E008B0B04.description: Describe the in uence of temperament and other social factors on attachment and appropriate socialization

0638EE2F9B2A4C09A903D5AC4F8CD1A1.description: Explain the process of conception and gestation, including factors that in uence successful fetal development (e g , nutrition, illness, substance abuse)

41760C971C024AF19DE1B758E409143F.description: Discuss the interaction of nature and nurture (including cultural variations) in the determination of behavior

84EB2F15A2634BF38A639EC10AA9E314.description: Identify key contributors in the psychology of motivation and emotion (e g , William James, Alfred Kinsey, Abraham Maslow, Stanley Schachter, Hans Selye)

5862FA5C27D4400B90A4B323BF75A7C4.description: Describe how cultural in uences shape emotional expression, including variations in body language

54D3529F1EA74299AE3E102668A701F7.description: Compare and contrast major theories of emotion (e g , James–Lange, Cannon– Bard, Schachter two-factor theory)

216324C9C5EC490F80FF7363E49B37AD.description: Discuss theories of stress and the effects of stress on psychological and physical well-being

C570246D0F9F4303B18FF90E7D4FE8EC.description: Describe classic research  ndings in speci c motivation systems (e g , eating, sex, social)

78BAE26B49014FC290FCE74E4E697AC3.description: Compare and contrast motivational theories (e g , drive reduction theory, arousal theory, general adaptation theory), including the strengths and weaknesses of each

CD53632531E64A3A96EA71E39963769B.description: Discuss the biological underpinnings of motivation, including needs, drives, and homeostasis

8486A442737C469297FB7479EAB0346A.description: Identify and apply basic motivational concepts to understand the behavior of humans and other animals (e g , instincts, incentives, intrinsic versus extrinsic motivation)

9ABD2B26753C4AC0A6F735081B2C82BF.description: Identify key contributors in cognitive psychology (e g , Noam Chomsky, Hermann Ebbinghaus, Wolfgang Köhler, Elizabeth Loftus, George A  Miller)

22134A7E78A248E7AA266B373F90E640.description: List the characteristics of creative thought and creative thinkers

CDC07B5093C34C5E8E2F6FAB2C167481.description: Identify problem-solving strategies as well as factors that in uence their effectiveness

5575E2D239474816B4C171BECA9D0CEC.description: Synthesize how biological, cognitive, and cultural factors converge to facilitate acquisition, development, and use of language

A9AA96E60306442F8AD2FC3593C30946.description: Outline the principles that underlie effective encoding, storage, and construction of memories

0606C3B9586743199A6B8A402CDF1C2C.description: Describe and differentiate psychological and physiological systems of memory (e g , short-term memory, procedural memory)

6C8DFBF3D5C3467486E345A7DFBCB936.description: Identify key contributors in the psychology of learning (e g , Albert Bandura, John Garcia, Ivan Pavlov, Robert Rescorla, B  F  Skinner, Edward Thorndike, Edward Tolman, John B  Watson)

5233987B262448638DB948FA56DDD587.description: Suggest how behavior modi cation, biofeedback, coping strategies, and self- control can be used to address behavioral problems

7A09403BF4654D749667167DAD4B6982.description: Apply learning principles to explain emotional learning, taste aversion, superstitious behavior, and learned helplessness

A8C7E8424A8149248F9DE49077AD9552.description: Describe the essential characteristics of insight learning, latent learning, and social learning

B3A9EA8D0374449292F7843DD9CD98BB.description: Provide examples of how biological constraints create learning predispositions

9F45FCAE506A4FFC8FBF9BC810CE3487.description: Interpret graphs that exhibit the results of learning experiments

5ED3BAD8DBEE452393DF8AEB8FFD9B64.description: Predict how practice, schedules of reinforcement, and motivation will in uence quality of learning

13E9499BD3E44FD9A403D3665C9F3F81.description: Predict the effects of operant conditioning (e g , positive reinforcement, negative reinforcement, punishment)

53B3AF42516946ADB84577805191A1A8.description: Describe basic classical conditioning phenomena, such as acquisition, extinction, spontaneous recovery, generalization, discrimination, and higher-order learning.

2B8364215EC8403581C91A347B86A15B.description: Distinguish general differences between principles of classical conditioning, operant conditioning, and observational learning (e g , contingencies)

3994401301E34E61A178DB4B06C0C340.description: Identify the major  gures in consciousness research (e g , William James, Sigmund Freud, Ernest Hilgard)

F0B9AE2CE75B44759C5DE93EC82F4049.description: Discuss drug dependence, addiction, tolerance, and withdrawal

A389AAEF6A314D9E829BA75C89D4D910.description:
Identify the major psychoactive drug categories (e g , depressants, stimulants) and classify specific drugs, including their psychological and physiological
effects

7C6186AD5A914652BBD562CD83A30D5A.description: Explain hypnotic phenomena (e g , suggestibility, dissociation)

2E6DBECB5C4349DE84F545F91A7BEB6B.description: Describe historic and contemporary uses of hypnosis (e g , pain control, psychotherapy)

9223DA8715F549E49D88B76AF3CED657.description: Describe various states of consciousness and their impact on behavior

EEC54B73E358459FBAF33159116AB7C2.description: Identify the major historical  gures in sensation and perception (e g , Gustav Fechner, David Hubel, Ernst Weber, Torsten Wiesel)

38EA0C7844754CA2B91396A4C0D62711.description: Challenge common beliefs in parapsychological phenomena

287415B946F44A59A95B6ECD856E2F63.description: Discuss the role of attention in behavior

86C3B05D49B3414485AB8E98729BD92A.description: Explain the role of top-down processing in producing vulnerability to illusion

C80A4D027AA64102BEDF23B912917D9A.description: Discuss how experience and culture can in uence perceptual processes (e g , perceptual set, context effects)

DE9ED2906E594B0690DB6CE00B6B446A.description: Describe general principles of organizing and integrating sensation to promote stable awareness of the external world (e g , Gestalt principles, depth perception)

0E77600F477940C4A0794894C4C92BE7.description: Explain common sensory disorders (e g , visual and hearing impairments)

A0C13603CBD74680A4EBFB642FF836A3.description: Describe sensory processes (e g , hearing, vision, touch, taste, smell, vestibular, kinesthesis, pain), including the speci c nature of energy transduction, relevant anatomical structures, and specialized pathways in the brain for each of the senses

E6B2401FADEE49D7B517A963238CA5F5.description: Discuss basic principles of sensory transduction, including absolute threshold, difference threshold, signal detection, and sensory adaptation

A58A66F6DB464C43B050A93F5B486B6F.description: Identify key contributors (e g , Paul Broca, Charles Darwin, Michael Gazzaniga, Roger Sperry, Carl Wernicke)

9233327C36AF4444914FF31FFB5FC5F6.description: Predict how traits and behavior can be selected for their adaptive value

830B888DF597434AAA26753177FCDE7F.description: Discuss psychology’s abiding interest in how heredity, environment, and evolution work together to shape behavior

BB6D488082CB4F45A689412ACF2AAE63.description: Recount historic and contemporary research strategies and technologies that support research (e g , case studies, split-brain research, imaging techniques)

DBD4530F2F434065B12131BA98AF3869.description: Discuss the role of neuroplasticity in traumatic brain injury

6DA3A5D417634BCD968820B2628508EA.description: Discuss the effect of the endocrine system on behavior

725E30384050421DB209D37F8293BCAD.description: Discuss the in uence of drugs on neurotransmitters (e g , reuptake mechanisms, agonists, antagonists)

947298DD55AE44ED92BA3BC6FB67518B.description: Identify basic processes and systems in the biological bases of behavior, including parts of the neuron and the process of transmission of a signal between neurons

A872E3A7B3224D62B22C344618D2081D.description: Describe how ethical and legal guidelines (e g , those provided by the American Psychological Association, federal regulations, local institutional review boards) protect research participants and promote sound ethical practice

04A8A364210041EFBA2C7F9054E6C182.description: Identify how ethical issues inform and constrain research practices

DDAF562782D248EBBD59AB952C2E3FD1.description: Discuss the value of reliance on operational de nitions and measurement in behavioral research

A41BF09E964D49C89BD1C4DBCC8EB23D.description:
Apply basic descriptive statistical concepts, including interpreting and constructing graphs and calculating simple descriptive statistics
(e g , measures of central tendency, standard deviation)

251B33491E3C4DE7825AFD6685752FF3.description: Distinguish the purposes of descriptive statistics and inferential statistics

0B449DF9E38847EF9887B9126735120E.description: Predict the validity of behavioral explanations based on the quality of research design (e g , confounding variables limit con dence in research conclusions)

5506688767A8459FBAD3CE84AE562173.description: Distinguish between random assignment of participants to conditions in experiments and random selection of participants, primarily in correlational studies and surveys

D1894264C88B4E0487527B0325C126BE.description: Identify independent, dependent, confounding, and control variables in experimental designs

A5ADBD5AB13E4D62B0AD61FACE915BD8.description: Describe how research design drives the reasonable conclusions that can be drawn (e g , experiments are useful for determining cause and effect; the use of experimental controls reduces alternative explanations)

3684FC51276C4F2EAE76A3E55BDBB644.description: Differentiate types of research (e g , experiments, correlational studies, survey research, naturalistic observations, case studies) with regard to purpose, strengths, and weaknesses

7830D6D6A38D428DB2686C145EEF1576.description: Identify major historical  gures in psychology (e g , Mary Whiton Calkins, Charles Darwin, Dorothea Dix, Sigmund Freud, G  Stanley Hall, William James, Ivan Pavlov, Jean Piaget, Carl Rogers, B  F  Skinner, Margaret Floy Washburn, John B  Watson, Wilhelm Wundt)

D96E8D76AE154B50BB23B61F4F0B0C38.description: Distinguish the different domains of psychology (e g , biological, clinical, cognitive, counseling, developmental, educational, experimental, human factors, industrial–organizational, personality, psychometric, social)

3E028EEA881A4218AD332773E98E5AF0.description: Recognize the strengths and limitations of applying theories to explain behavior

F6447F569BFE4C7CA755D0227D5E1364.description: Recognize how philosophical and physiological perspectives shaped the development of psychological thought
